pageProps.body:
Principle Component Analysis

Given X=[x0,…,xn]∈Rf×n\bm{X} = \begin{bmatrix} \bm{x}_0, \dots, \bm{x}_n \end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb{R}^{f \times n}X=[x0​,…,xn​​]∈Rf×n, n≪fn \ll fn≪f, find a set of basis W=[w1,…,wk]T∈Rf×d\bm{W} = \begin{bmatrix} \bm{w}_1, \dots, \bm{w}_k \end{bmatrix}^T \in \mathbb{R}^{f \times d}W=[w1​,…,wk​​]T∈Rf×d, such that variance of the linear projection of xi\bm{x}_ixi​ on w\bm{w}w is maximized. See Dot product as projection

Brief Derivation

yi=WTxiyi−μy=WTxi−WTμx=WTx‾iσY=1n∑i=1n(yi−μy)(yi−μy)T=1n∑i=1nWTx‾ix‾iTW=tr(WTStW)\bm{y}_i = \bm{W}^T \bm{x}_i \\ \bm{y}_i - \mu_{\bm{y}} = \bm{W}^T \bm{x}_i - \bm{W}^T \bm{\mu}_{\bm{x}} = \bm{W}^T \overline{\bm{x}}_i\\ \sigma_{\bm{Y}} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} (\bm{y}_i - \mu_{\bm{y}})(\bm{y}_i - \mu_{\bm{y}})^T = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \bm{W}^T \overline{\bm{x}}_i \overline{\bm{x}}_i^T \bm{W} = tr(\bm{W}^T \bm{S}_t \bm{W}) \\yi​=WTxi​yi​−μy​=WTxi​−WTμx​=WTxi​σY​=n1​i=1∑n​(yi​−μy​)(yi​−μy​)T=n1​i=1∑n​WTxi​xiT​W=tr(WTSt​W)

So for objective function:

Wo=arg max⁡Wσy=arg max⁡Wtr(WTStW)\begin{aligned} \bm{W}_o &= \argmax_{\bm{W}} \sigma_{\bm{y}} \\ &= \argmax_{\bm{W}} tr(\bm{W}^T \bm{S}_t \bm{W}) \end{aligned}Wo​​=Wargmax​σy​=Wargmax​tr(WTSt​W)​

We incorperate with constraint WTW=I\bm{W}^T \bm{W} = \bm{I}WTW=I and fomulate with Lagrangian:

L(W,Λ)=tr(WTStW)−tr(Λ(WTW−I))L(\bm{W}, \bm{\Lambda}) = tr(\bm{W}^T \bm{S}_t \bm{W}) - tr(\bm{\Lambda}(\bm{W}^T \bm{W} - \bm{I}))L(W,Λ)=tr(WTSt​W)−tr(Λ(WTW−I))

Compute its derivative over W\bm{W}W and set it to 0. See: Differentiation Formulas. Note St\bm{S}_tSt​ is positive semi-definte matrix (non-negative eigenvalues), Λ\bm{\Lambda}Λ is diagonal matrix.

∂L∂W=tr(2WTSt)−tr(2ΛWT)=0StW=WΛ\frac{\partial L}{\partial \bm{W}} = tr(2\bm{W}^T \bm{S}_t) - tr(2 \bm{\Lambda} \bm{W}^T) = 0 \\ \bm{S}_t \bm{W} = \bm{W} \bm{\Lambda} \\∂W∂L​=tr(2WTSt​)−tr(2ΛWT)=0St​W=WΛ

Stwk=λkwk\bm{S}_t \bm{w}_k = \lambda_k \bm{w}_kSt​wk​=λk​wk​ for i=1,…,ki=1,\dots,ki=1,…,k. Thus, W\bm{W}W column-wise are ddd eignvectors of St\bm{S}_tSt​.

From Eigendecomposition, we have St=UΛUT\bm{S}_t = \bm{U} \bm{\Lambda} \bm{U}^TSt​=UΛUT, Ud=W\bm{U}_d = \bm{W}Ud​=W. Go back to objective function

tr(WTStW)=tr(WTUΛUTW)=tr(Λd)=∑k=1dλktr(\bm{W}^T \bm{S}_t \bm{W}) = tr(\bm{W}^T \bm{U} \bm{\Lambda} \bm{U}^T \bm{W}) = tr(\bm{\Lambda}_d) = \sum_{k=1}^{d} \lambda_ktr(WTSt​W)=tr(WTUΛUTW)=tr(Λd​)=k=1∑d​λk​

We choose ddd eignvectors that corresponds to ddd largest eigenvalues

Computation

For X∈Rf×n\bm{X} \in \mathbb{R}^{f \times n}X∈Rf×n, n≪fn \ll fn≪f, XXT∈Rf×f\bm{X}\bm{X}^T \in \mathbb{R}^{f \times f}XXT∈Rf×f is more computational expensive to compute than XTX∈Rn×n\bm{X}^T \bm{X} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}XTX∈Rn×n.

Since they share the same eigenvalues, we eigendecompose XTX=VΛVT\bm{X}^T \bm{X} = \bm{V} \bm{\Lambda} \bm{V}^TXTX=VΛVT and compute U=XVΛ−12\bm{U} = \bm{X} \bm{V} \bm{\Lambda} ^ {-\frac{1}{2}}U=XVΛ−21​. See proof.

We pick ddd eigenvectors (columns of U\bm{U}U) and projected feature

Y=UdTX\bm{Y} = \bm{U}_d^T \bm{X}Y=UdT​X

Note the covariance of projected feature

YYT=UdTXXTUd=Λd\bm{Y} \bm{Y}^T = \bm{U}_d^T \bm{X} \bm{X}^T \bm{U}_d = \bm{\Lambda}_dYYT=UdT​XXTUd​=Λd​

which means projected features are uncorrelated

Whiten

If we wish YYT=I\bm{Y} \bm{Y}^T = \bm{I}YYT=I

W=UdΛd−12\bm{W} = \bm{U}_d \bm{\Lambda}_d^{-\frac{1}{2}}W=Ud​Λd−21​​

Kernel Trick

Instead of explicitly define ϕ(.)\phi(.)ϕ(.), define it implicitly using similarity function via Inner Product

k(xi,xj)=⟨ϕ(xi),ϕ(xj)⟩k(\bm{x}_i, \bm{x}_j) = \langle \phi(\bm{x}_i), \phi(\bm{x}_j) \ranglek(xi​,xj​)=⟨ϕ(xi​),ϕ(xj​)⟩

PCA example

Suppose fff is very large (e.g. infinity) that is intractable, but XTX\bm{X}^T \bm{X}XTX is solvable

XTX=[k(x1,x1)…k(x1,xn)⋮⋱k(xn,x1)k(xn,xn)]∈Rn×n\bm{X}^T \bm{X} = \begin{bmatrix} k(x_1, x_1) & \dots & k(x_1, x_n) \\ \vdots & \ddots & \\ k(x_n, x_1) & & k(x_n, x_n) \end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}XTX=⎣⎡​k(x1​,x1​)⋮k(xn​,x1​)​…⋱​k(x1​,xn​)k(xn​,xn​)​⎦⎤​∈Rn×n

We can still compute PCA

XTX=VΛVT\bm{X}^T \bm{X} = \bm{V} \bm{\Lambda} \bm{V}^TXTX=VΛVT
Y=UdTX=(XVΛ−12)TX=VTΛ−12(XTX)\bm{Y} = \bm{U}_d^T \bm{X} = (\bm{X} \bm{V} \bm{\Lambda} ^ {-\frac{1}{2}})^T \bm{X} = \bm{V}^T \bm{\Lambda} ^ {-\frac{1}{2}} (\bm{X}^T \bm{X})Y=UdT​X=(XVΛ−21​)TX=VTΛ−21​(XTX)

During inference, for test sample xt∈Rf×1\bm{x}_t \in \mathbb{R}^{f \times 1}xt​∈Rf×1

yt=VTΛ−12(XTxt)y_t = \bm{V}^T \bm{\Lambda} ^ {-\frac{1}{2}} (\bm{X}^T \bm{x}_t)yt​=VTΛ−21​(XTxt​)

where

XTxt=[k(x1,xt)⋮k(xn,xt)]\bm{X}^T \bm{x}_t = \begin{bmatrix} k(x_1, x_t) \\ \vdots \\ k(x_n, x_t) \end{bmatrix}XTxt​=⎣⎡​k(x1​,xt​)⋮k(xn​,xt​)​⎦⎤​
Backlinks

  • Signed Distance Function
  • Moving Least Square

noteIndex.title: Root
noteIndex.body:
My personal knowledge cache using [Dendron](https://www.dendron.so)

## History
It was during my first job, at the start-up company called PixelShift.AI, that I acquired most prominent skill as a software engineer-the ability to read source code. It opened up a new way of learning and my knowledge expanded rapidly ever since. Learning new things is thriving but noting them down cogently and organized is hard. I often found myself forget the context few month later, making the notes completely intelligible. Additionally, some notes need frequent update as my previous understanding could be parochial, antiquated or even erroneous.

In desperate attempt to facilitate the noting/updating experience, I came across [Dendron](https://www.dendron.so) and found it surprisingly congenial to my personal need. With it, I have gradually grown the habit of caching, linking back and extending my knowledge base.

## Disclaimer
The notes are collections of information I found along the journey. I use backquote to denote sources, but I am likely to miss some references, so apology in advance. Also, they are my personal understandings, usually added when I first encounter the topic and will be updated only when I come across it again, so some of them could be incomplete or wrong.
